clinical_study.brief_title: Upper-airway Changes After Bimaxillary Advancement in OSAHS
clinical_study.official_title: Upper-airway Changes After Bimaxillary Advancement in Moderate-severe Obstructive Sleep Apnoea / Hypopnoea Syndrome

brief_summary.textblock:
One of the most effective surgical treatments for obstructive sleep apnoea / hypopnoea syndrome (SAHS) with global impact on the upper-airway (UA) is the maxilla-mandibular advancement (MMA). Retrospective-prospective observational study of: clinical outcomes, UA and dental-cranium-facial (DCF) morphology.
Population sample will be patients treated in the Maxillofacial Surgery department of "Hospital de Cruces". As inclusion criteria: ≥18 years-old, moderate-severe SAHS in supine position, multidisciplinary committee of sleep pathology evaluation for surgical indication, and written informed consents. As exclusion criteria: pregnant woman, SAHS of central origin, cranium-facial deformities that significantly modify normal UA, different surgery than MMA and inconclusive / incomplete tests. It is estimated ≥90% males; ≥90% 30-59 years-old; ≤10% extreme weights; 25% complementary surgeries; and sample size 40. Medical ethics code of the Declaration of Helsinki will be taken into account. To collect the pre- / postoperative data we will use, calibrated and standardized: polysomnography (PSG), computed tomography (CT), right face profile picture (RFP) and lateral teleradiography of the cranium (LTC). Furthermore, the Epworth scale and non-validated subjective self-perception test of facial aesthetics will be performed.
Clinical outcomes will be evaluated from PSG using apnoea / hypopnoea index and pulse oximeter oxygen saturation, and from Epworth scale. UA morphology from CT, globally and by specific locations, through lengths, volumes, areas, dimensions, and other measurements. DCF aspects from RFP and LTC, by Ricketts cephalometric basic analysis and facial aesthetics test. Statistical, descriptive analysis of frequencies and comparative by pairs of quantitative data will be by t-Student or Wilcoxon test, after checking the variables normality with the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test.

detailed_description.textblock:
HYPOTHESIS:
H0: Upper-airway (UA) morphology does not change as a consequence of maxilla-mandibular advancement (MMA) in patients with moderate-severe obstructive sleep apnoea / hypopnoea syndrome (SAHS).
H1: UA changes as a consequence of MMA in patients with moderate-severe SAHS. To answer this hypothesis, the following will be determined: Vertical UA length, volume, axial areas, ellipticity, uniformity, prevertebral soft tissue (PST) and soft palate (SP) lengths and position of the hyoid bone.
As secondary hypotheses:
H0: Clinical outcomes of MMA in moderate-severe SAHS are not successful. H1: Clinical outcomes of MMA in moderate-severe SAHS are successful. To answer, the apnoea / hypopnoea index (AHI), pulse oximeter oxygen saturation (SPO2) and daytime sleepiness will be determined.
H0: DCF morphology is unfavourable as a result of MMA in moderate-severe SAHS. H1: DCF morphology is not unfavourable as a result of MMA in moderate-severe SAHS.
To answer, the parameters of the Ricketts cephalometric basic analysis will be quantified and interpreted, and the patient's self-perception will be assessed.
OBJECTIVES:
Specify and quantify morphological changes in key anatomical locations of the UA by computed tomography (CT), in terms of vertical lengths, volumes, areas, axial dimensions, and other measurements. These changes happen after MMA surgery in patients diagnosed with moderate-severe SAHS from a representative cohort. We are intended to demonstrate: shortening, increase in volume and areas, more elliptical and uniform shape, modifications of PST and SP and more anterior-superior hyoid bone position.
As secondary objectives, inherent to the treatment received, it is first intended to determine and evaluate clinical outcomes: objectively by PSG, and subjectively by the Epworth scale. Secondary, it is intended to specify and quantify changes in DCF morphology: objectively by a two-dimensional cephalometric analysis from lateral teleradiography of the cranium (LTC) and right face profile picture (RFP), and subjectively by a non-validated facial aesthetics test (FAT).
1. DESIGN:
Observational retrospective-prospective study, which does not make any modification of the usual clinical practice (surgical indication criteria, procedures, examinations, surgical techniques...), of: clinical outcomes, UA morphology, and DCF aspects of SAHS patients undergoing MMA.
- Logistic and organizational process for the participants: Explanations, invitation to participate, resolution of doubts, delivery of written information sheet and informed consent, collection of them and FAT. Everything will be done in two face-to-face clinic consultations that are already part of the usual work protocol of the Maxillofacial Surgery department of our hospital for patients with SAHS. It is estimated that it only involves about 10-15 minutes per consultation of extra time, without the need of additional specific appointments for the present study. With regard to clinical history, complementary examinations and surgical procedure, nothing additional is required regarding the usual workflow for SAHS patients in our department.
- Logistic and organizational process for researchers: It is based on office and digital work, without biological samples.
2. PARTICIPANTS:
Population sample are patients treated in a single centre: Maxillofacial Surgery department, "Hospital de Cruces". The time period of the retrospective aspect is from 01/01/2012 to 02/25/2020, the date of acceptance by the regional ethics committee of clinical investigation "CEIC OSI Exkerraldea-Enkarterri-Cruces". The time period of the prospective aspect is from that date until 01/31/2021.
Inclusion criteria are: ≥18 years-old, diagnosis by PSG of moderate-severe SAHS in supine position, approval of the surgical indication by the multidisciplinary sleep committee of our hospital, written informed consent (IC) of photography or image recording, orthognathic surgery program inclusion and facial deformity surgery. In addition, previous information and indispensable with the facial deformity IC signed and delivered, the patient must grant the specific IC for inclusion in the present study.
Regarding the retrospective cohort, in a face-to-face appointment of scheduled outpatient consultation, the patient will be explained and invited to participate in this study. Questions will be resolved and the specific IC and information sheet (for the retrospective cohort) of the study will be delivered for reading. In other consultation, specific IC will be signed if the patient accepts participation and more doubts will be resolved if they arise. The time between the two consultations will be at least one week.
Regarding the prospective cohort, having previously granted the signed facial deformity surgery IC, either in scheduled outpatient consultation or in team session, the patient will be explained and invited to participate in this study. Questions will be resolved and the specific IC and information sheet (for the prospective cohort) of the study will be delivered for reading. In other consultation, specific IC will be signed if the patient accepts participation and more doubts will be resolved if they arise. The time between the two appointments will be at least one week and must be before having performed the MMA surgery. Refusing to participate will not have any change or involvement in the treatment and monitoring of the patient (techniques, complementary examinations, clinical appointments…).
Exclusion criteria are: pregnant woman, central SAHS, medical-surgical history (trauma, tumour, major congenital craniofacial deformity) that significantly alter the normal UA anatomy, different orthognathic surgery than MMA and inconclusive / incomplete tests and data.
≥90% of men are expected in the sample with respect to the gender perspective; ≥90% with age range 30-59 years-old; ≤10% extreme weights; 40% without facial deformity or malocclusion; and 25% with complementary surgeries with added impact on UA at the same time of the MMA., A sample size of 40 subjects is estimated, compiling previous studies and the Granmo® calculator. This would achieve significant statistics in all the parameters considered to answer the main hypothesis, and most of the secondary ones.
The Declaration of Helsinki code of medical ethics for research in human beings will be taken into account, protecting the health of the participant, being voluntary the inclusion, interrupting the investigation if it can be detrimental to the well-being of the participant and agreement of confidentiality in the IC. The "CEIC OSI Exkerraldea-Enkarterri-Cruces" committee has approved the study (Code CEIC E19/39).
3. VARIABLES:
For the collection of pre- / postoperative data we will use the following medical tests: Clinical history, scale / test (Epworth and FAT) and complementary calibrated and standardized examinations (PSG, CT, RFP and LTC). The pre- must have been made 3 months before the MMA and the post- 3 months after it. A "data collection sheet", coded by a number in chronological order by the date of the surgery, will be done for each participant. All these data will be non-identifying and collected in an Excel® file, called SAHS-2. The code of each patient can only be related to their medical history and other alphanumeric data in a different encrypted Excel® file, called SAHS-1, to maintain confidentiality. Only the principal investigator will have access and the SAHS-1 password.
Identifying data of the patient are: name, surname, hospital history number, dates (recruitment, birth, surgery, PSG pre- / post-, Epworth pre- / post-, CT pre- / post, RFP pre- / post-, LTC pre- / post-, FAT).
General data to be collected are: code, informed consent (yes / no), cohort (retrospective / prospective). As background: age (in years-old); ethnicity (white / pacific islander / latino / black / asian / american indian); sex (male / female), weight (in kg), height (in m), body mass index (kg/m^2), Angle class (I / II / III), Mallampati scale(I / II / III / IV)). As planning movements: anterior advancement at the central superior incisor (in mm), vertical movement measured at the same place (in mm), posterior vertical movement at the upper right and left first molar (in mm). As other data: previous UA related surgery (septoplasty, adenoidectomy, tonsillectomy, uvulopalatopharyngoplasty, surgically assisted rapid palatal expansion...), simultaneous UA related surgery (genioplasty, genioglossus advancement...), repositioning system, follow-up timing), complications (intraoperative, short-, medium-, long-term).
Clinical outcomes will be evaluated from PSG using AHI (global, supine and lateral), apnoea number (obstructive, central, mixed), hypopnoea number, and SPO2 (mean, basal and minimum); and from the daytime sleepiness Epworth scale (0 to 24).
UA morphology will be evaluated from CT scans, globally and by compartments: retropalatal (RP), retro-glossal (RG) and hypopharynx (HPh). The axial series in digital imaging and communications in medicine (DICOM) format is imported into the measurement software. Coronal, sagittal and three-dimensional reconstructions are performed automatically. The working skull is oriented manually with anatomical references: nasopalatine duct, odontoid apophysis, crista galli, anterior nasal spine (ANS) and posterior (PNS), most antero-inferior point of the second cervical vertebra (AIC2). The main planes are defined in a midsagittal section: the hard palate (HP) (ANS-PNS) and the perpendicular plane that passes through AIC2. The compartments are delimited by planes parallel to HP plane that pass through the uvula tip (UT), epiglottis tip (ET) and the inferior edge of the hyoid bone (IEHB). Vertical longitudinal measurements (in mm) are taken parallel to the AIC2 plane: total, RP, RG, HPh and summation. Air volume (in mm^3) is delimited by antero-posterior-lateral soft tissues: total, RP, RG, HPh and summation. Areas (in mm^2) are measured in axial slices: HP plane, parallel UT, ET, IEHB and minimum. Anteroposterior and transverse dimensions, understood as maximum continuous length in the same axial slices of the areas, are taken. Other horizontal lengths, parallel to the HP plane and from the AIC2 one, are registered: PST and antero-inferior hyoid bone point. Also, the soft palate length is measured. Average area, ellipticity, uniformity and vertical length correction formulas are applied.
The DCF parameters will be evaluated from the RFP and LTC, using the Ricketts basic cephalometric analysis. They are imported in jpg format the software measure, calibrate and merge them. The following cephalometric points are marked: sella, nasion (Na), basion (Ba), orbital, porion, pterion, ANS, PNS, A, B, pogonion, chin protrusion, chin, gonion, gnathion, condylion, upper and lower incisor apex, upper and lower incisor root, occlusal of molars, glabella, soft Na, nasal eminence, columella, subnasal, soft A, soft B, chin-tangent, chin eminence, soft gnathion and soft chin. The points of the condyle neck and mandibular ramus centre (Xi) are drawn automatically; and the following cephalometric planes: occlusal, Frankfurt, facial, mandibular, facial axis, mandibular body axis, condylar axis, Ba-Na line, Na-A line, dental line, Xi-ANS line, pterygoid vertical, upper and lower central incisor axis and Ricketts E line. Cephalometric factors are automatically obtained. In the mandibular area are: facial axis angle (in grades), facial depth (in grades), mandibular plane angle (in grades), lower facial height (in mm), mandibular arch (in grades). In the maxillary area: facial convexity (in mm), maxillary depth (in grades). In the dental area: incisor protrusion (in mm), inclination (in grades), extrusion (in mm), interincisal angle (in grades) and upper molar position (in mm). In the aesthetic area: labial protrusion (in mm).
DCF morphology will also be assessed by the patient itself subjectively, from the FAT with the following items: general satisfaction (none / little / ok / a lot of) modifications perceived by the patient itself (much worse / worse / no changes / better / much better), modifications perceived by family members and friends (much worse / worse / no changes / better / much better), smile (much worse / worse / no changes / better / much better), face rejuvenation (older / no changes / younger) and face slimness (bulkier / no changes / slimmer).
4. DATA ANALYSIS:
All qualitative and quantitative non-identifying data will be coded and sorted in an Excel® table, mark as SAHS-2. Once exported to the statistical analysis software, we will analyze the qualitative and continuous quantitative variables in categorical variables. Descriptive statistics of frequencies will be calculated. For statistical inference, only comparisons are made between two continuous variables, all dependent and paired (pre- / post-). To verify that the variables follow a normal distribution, the Kolmogorov-Smirnov statistic will be used. The comparisons will then be made with the t-Student test for two dependent samples or the Wilcoxon ranks test if they do not follow a normal distribution. Statistically significant results will be considered if p ˂0.05.
5. STUDY LIMITATIONS:
In terms of inclusion and exclusion criteria, the women representation will be too little to stratify by gender. Other ages different form the fourth-fifth decades and the prospective cohort will be too small as well to analyze independently. Additional surgeries at the same time of the MMA overestimate the favourable impact on UA and DCF outcomes.
As an observational study, it is not possible to perform randomization, since all participants undergo the same MMA surgery. There is hardly any possibility of applying blinding. Surgical planning, clinical examination for the study (PSG, CT, LTC, RFP, Epworth), even the surgical act itself, are externally protocolized from the study, with its inherent acquisition and execution errors. UA and cephalometric measurements cannot be blinded to the researcher, since the evidence betrays which cases are pre- or post- due to the presence of osteosynthesis material. There are other measurement automatic methods, other references and also valid measures that have not been considered, as in the nasal cavity or the nasopharynx space. The statistical analysis cannot be blinded because the intervention is the same in all cases and is performed independently pre- / post- to compare them afterwards.
There are also inherent errors in computer algorithms for measurements and statistical analysis, especially in those that are not open-access.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 year
primary_outcome.description: From computed-tomography examinations. Total, retropalatal compartment, retro-glossal compartment, hypopharynx compartment and summatory. Measured in mm.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 year
primary_outcome.description: From computed-tomography examinations. Total, retropalatal compartment, retro-glossal compartment, hypopharynx compartment and summatory. Measured in mm^3.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 year
primary_outcome.description: From computed-tomography examinations. Minimum, hard palate plane, parallel uvula tip plane, parallel epiglottis tip plane, parallel inferior edge of the hyoid bone plane. Measured in mm. Measured in mm^2.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 year
primary_outcome.description: A formula: transversal dimension / anteroposterior dimension. Dimensions characteristics are: From computed-tomography examinations. Minimum, hard palate plane, parallel uvula tip plane, parallel epiglottis tip plane, parallel inferior edge of the hyoid bone plane. Measured in mm.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 year
primary_outcome.description: A formula: minimum area / (hard palate area + uvula tip area + epiglottis tip area + hyoid bone area) Measured in units from 0 to 1.

primary_outcome.measure: Upper-airway morphology: prevertebral soft tissue length

primary_outcome.description: From computed-tomography examinations. Measured in mm.

primary_outcome.description: From computed-tomography examinations. Measured in mm in the anteroposterior aspect and also the superoinferior aspect, this one is the same measure as vertical length.

arm_group.description: Moderate-severe obstructive sleep apnoea / hypopnoea patients, preoperative
Moderate-severe obstructive sleep apnoea / hypopnoea patients, postoperative

intervention.description: Maxilla: Lefort I osteotomy Mandible: Obwegeser-Dal-Pont osteotomy Movements: Advance and counterclockwise rotation

study_pop.textblock: Adult patients treated in a single centre: Maxillofacial Surgery department, "Hospital de Cruces", Barakaldo, Spain Time period from 01/01/2012 to 01/31/2021.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- ≥18 years-old.
- Diagnosis by polysomnography of moderate-severe obstructive sleep apnoea / hypopnoea syndrome (SAHS) in supine position.
- Approval of the surgical indication by the multidisciplinary sleep committee of our hospital
- Written informed consent (IC) of photography or image recording, orthognathic surgery program inclusion and facial deformity surgery.
- Specific IC for inclusion in the present study.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant woman
- Central SAHS
- Medical-surgical history that significantly alter the normal upper-airway anatomy: trauma, tumour, major congenital craniofacial deformity
- Different orthognathic surgery than MMA
- Inconclusive / incomplete tests and data.

patient_data.ipd_description: General non-identifying subjects data Upper-airway morphology data Clinical outcomes data Dental-cranium-facial morphology data
